title: Activities vs. GPAs: Independence
question_text:
A random survey was conducted at a large suburban high school to determine if a relationship exists between being involved in extracurricular activities and higher grades.
The data is show in the two-way table below:
--MusicAthleticsBothNeitherTotal
GPA $<2.0$$8$$11$$4$$14$$37$
$2.0\le$ GPA $\le 3.0$$19$$19$$25$$16$$79$
GPA $\ge 3.0$$20$$7$$15$$17$$59$
Total$47$$37$$44$$47$$175$


What would be an appropriate calculation to show that having a high GPA (over $3.0$) and being involved in music are not independent?

choices.text:
The probability that GPA is over
3.0
is
33.7
%
. The probability that GPA is over
3.0
, among those in music, is
42.6
%
.

The probability that GPA is over
3.0
, among those in athletics, is
18.9
%
. The probability that GPA is over
3.0
, among those in music, is
42.6
%
.

The probability that GPA is over
3.0
, among those in neither music nor athletics, is
36.2
%
. The probability that GPA is over
3.0
, among those in music, is
42.6
%
.

The probability of being involved in music and athletics is
25.1
%
. The probability of being involved in music and athletics, given a GPA over
3.0
, is
25.4
%
.
No individual calculation can show this, as a chi-squared test would be necessary.
